Complete list of all CPCReady commands

import { Card, CardGrid } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

## Command Overview

CPCReady provides a comprehensive set of commands for managing Amstrad CPC disk images, files, and emulator integration. All commands are accessible through the `cpc` CLI.

---

## Disk Management

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="disc" icon="document">
    Manage DSK disk images
    
    - Create new blank disks
    - Insert disks into drives
    - Display disk information
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/disc/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="drive" icon="setting">
    Virtual floppy drive operations
    
    - Mount disks in drives A/B
    - Check drive status
    - Eject disks
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/drive/)
  </Card>
</CardGrid>

---

## File Operations

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="cat" icon="list-format">
    List all files on disk
    
    - Display file catalog
    - Show file sizes and types
    - Filter by user area
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/cat/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="save" icon="add-document">
    Save files to DSK disk
    
    - Binary files with AMSDOS headers
    - BASIC programs
    - ASCII text files
    - Automatic type detection
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/save/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="filextr" icon="document">
    Extract files from disk
    
    - Single or multiple files
    - Preserve AMSDOS headers
    - Extract to current directory
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/filextr/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="list" icon="open-book">
    Display BASIC programs
    
    - Detokenize BASIC files
    - Syntax highlighting
    - Support for ASCII BASIC
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/list/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="era" icon="trash">
    Delete files from disk
    
    - Single file deletion
    - Wildcard support (*.BAK)
    - Permanent removal
    
    [View Details ](../../reference/commands/era/)
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="ren" icon="pencil">
    Rename files on disk
    
    - Change file names

## Quick Command Reference

### Disk & Drive Commands

| Command | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|---------|
| `cpc disc new <file>` | Create blank DSK | `cpc disc new blank.dsk` |
| `cpc disc insert <file> -A` | Insert disk in drive A | `cpc disc insert game.dsk -A` |
| `cpc disc info -A` | Show disk information | `cpc disc info -A` |
| `cpc drive A <file>` | Mount disk in drive A | `cpc drive A system.dsk` |
| `cpc drive B <file>` | Mount disk in drive B | `cpc drive B games.dsk` |
| `cpc drive status` | Show drive status | `cpc drive status` |
| `cpc drive eject -A` | Eject from drive A | `cpc drive eject -A` |

### File Management Commands

| Command | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|---------|
| `cpc cat` | List files on disk | `cpc cat` |
| `cpc save <file> [type]` | Save file to disk | `cpc save loader.bin b 0x4000` |
| `cpc filextr <file>` | Extract file from disk | `cpc filextr GAME.BAS` |
| `cpc list <file>` | Display BASIC program | `cpc list MENU.BAS` |
| `cpc era <file>` | Delete file | `cpc era OLDFILE.BIN` |
| `cpc ren <old> <new>` | Rename file | `cpc ren OLD.BAS NEW.BAS` |

### System Commands

| Command | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|---------|
| `cpc model <464\|664\|6128>` | Set CPC model | `cpc model 6128` |
| `cpc mode <0\|1\|2>` | Set video mode | `cpc mode 1` |
| `cpc user <0-15>` | Set CP/M user | `cpc user 0` |
| `cpc settings` | Show all settings | `cpc settings` |
| `cpc configweb` | Launch GUI config | `cpc configweb` |
| `cpc run [file]` | Launch emulator | `cpc run GAME.BAS` |

import { Card, CardGrid } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Aside } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Tabs, TabItem } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
## What is CPCReady? **CPCReady** is a comprehensive command-line toolchain designed for Amstrad CPC enthusiasts and retro computing developers. It provides modern tools to manage disk images, files, and emulator integration from your contemporary development environment. Built with **Python 3.13+** and powered by **Poetry**, CPCReady brings professional development workflows to vintage computing.
Retro computing enthusiasts, game developers, BASIC programmers, and anyone working with Amstrad CPC disk images and emulators.
--- ## Core Features Create, format, and manage **.DSK** disk images with full CP/M compatibility. Support for 40 tracks, 9 sectors, 180KB standard format. Simulate dual floppy drives (A/B) with instant disk insertion, ejection, and status monitoring. Just like the real hardware. Save, extract, rename, delete, and list files on disk images. Full support for AMSDOS headers and file types (BASIC, Binary, ASCII). Launch **RetroVirtualMachine** with automatic configuration. Supports macOS .app bundles, process management, and file execution. Authentic CP/M user area support (0-15) for organizing files, just like on real CPC systems. Configure CPC model (464/664/6128), video mode (0/1/2), and system settings. --- ## Quick Start ### Essential Commands ```bash # Drive Status cpc drive status # List files on current disk cpc cat # Save a binary file with addresses cpc save loader.bin b 0x4000 0x4000 # Extract a file from disk cpc filextr GAME.BAS # Launch emulator with current disk cpc run "loader.bas" ``` ### File Types
  • b - Binary file (requires load/exec addresses)
  • p - Program file (preserves AMSDOS header)
  • a - ASCII/text file (no header)
  • auto - Automatic detection (default)
 ### Configuration File CPCReady stores settings in TOML format: **Location**: `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml` ```toml [drive] drive_a = "/path/to/system.dsk" drive_b = "/path/to/games.dsk" selected_drive = "A" [emulator] default = "RetroVirtualMachine" retro_virtual_machine_path = "/Applications/Retro Virtual Machine 2.app" [system] user = 0 # CP/M user area (0-15) model = "6128" # CPC model: 464, 664, or 6128 mode = 1 # Video mode: 0, 1, or 2 ``` ### GUI Configuration Launch the graphical configuration tool: ```bash cpc configweb ``` --- ## Command Categories **`disc`** - Create, insert, and inspect disk images - `disc new` - Create blank DSK - `disc insert` - Insert DSK into drive - `disc info` - Show disk information **`drive`** - Manage virtual floppy drives - `drive A/B` - Mount disk - `drive status` - Show drive status - `drive eject` - Eject disk **File operations** on disk images - `cat` - List all files - `save` - Save file to disk - `filextr` - Extract file - `era` - Delete file - `ren` - Rename file - `list` - Display BASIC program **Configuration and execution** - `run` - Launch emulator - `model` - Set CPC model - `mode` - Set video mode - `user` - Set CP/M user area --- ## Why CPCReady?
CPCReady bridges the gap between modern development environments and classic Amstrad CPC systems. Whether you're preserving old software, creating new retro games, or exploring vintage computing, CPCReady provides the professional tools you need.
### Key Advantages - ** Fast & Efficient**: Command-line interface for rapid workflows - ** Flexible**: Works with existing DSK files and emulators - ** Complete**: All tools in one package. - ** Accurate**: Proper AMSDOS header handling and CP/M compatibility - ** Cross-platform**: Python-based, runs on macOS, Linux, and Windows - ** Modern**: Built with Python 3.13+, type hints, and best practices --- ## Example Workflow Here's a typical development workflow with CPCReady: ```bash # 1. Create a new disk cpc disc new myproject.dsk # 2. Mount it in drive A cpc drive insert myproject.dsk -A # 3. Save your BASIC program cpc save menu.bas a # 4. Save a binary loader cpc save loader.bin b 0x4000 0x4000 # 5. List files to verify cpc cat # 6. Launch in emulator cpc run MENU.BAS ``` --- ## Open Source CPCReady is open source software licensed under **Apache License 2.0**.
--- ## Ready to Start? Follow our comprehensive installation guide to set up CPCReady on your system. [Get Started ](guides/install/) Explore all available commands with detailed examples and options. [View Commands ](guides/commands/) View release history and version changes. [View Changelog ](guides/changelog/)

How to install CPCReady on your system

import { Card, CardGrid } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

## Overview

**CPCReady** is a Python-based toolchain for managing Amstrad CPC disk images. Follow this guide to install it on your system.

<Aside type="note">
CPCReady works on **macOS**, **Linux**, and **Windows** (via WSL). Python 3.13+ and Poetry are required.
</Aside>

---

## System Requirements

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="Python 3.13+" icon="seti:python">
    Download from [python.org](https://www.python.org/downloads/)
    
    Verify installation:
    ```bash
    python3 --version
    ```
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="Poetry" icon="seti:config">
    Package manager for Python
    
    Install with:
    ```bash
    curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -
    ```
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="Git" icon="github">
    Version control system
    
    Verify installation:
    ```bash
    git --version
    ```
  </Card>
  
  <Card title="RetroVirtualMachine (Optional)" icon="laptop">
    Amstrad CPC emulator
    
    Download from [retrovirtualmachine.org](https://www.retrovirtualmachine.org/)
  </Card>
</CardGrid>

---

## Installation Methods

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="From Source (Recommended)">

### Install from GitHub Repository

<Steps>

1. **Clone the repository**
   
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/CPCReady/cpc.git
   cd cpc
   ```

2. **Install with Poetry**
   
   ```bash
   poetry install
   ```

3. **Verify installation**
   
   ```bash
   poetry run cpc --version
   ```

4. **Optional: Add to PATH**
   
   For easier access, you can create an alias in your shell:
   
   ```bash
   # For bash/zsh, add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
   alias cpc='poetry run cpc'
   ```

</Steps>

<Aside type="tip">
Installing from source gives you the latest features and allows you to contribute to development.
</Aside>

  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="From PyPI (Future)">

### Install from Python Package Index

<Aside type="caution">
PyPI package is not yet available. Use the "From Source" method for now.
</Aside>

When available, you'll be able to install with:

```bash
pip install cpcready
```

Verify installation:

```bash
cpc --version
```

Update to latest version:

```bash
pip install --upgrade cpcready
```

  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Post-Installation Setup

### 1. Configure CPCReady

Run the configuration wizard:

```bash
poetry run cpc configweb
```

Or manually edit the configuration file:

**Location**: `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml`

```toml
[drive]
drive_a = ""
drive_b = ""
selected_drive = "A"

[emulator]
default = "RetroVirtualMachine"
retro_virtual_machine_path = "/Applications/Retro Virtual Machine 2.app"

[system]
user = 0
model = "6128"
mode = 1
```

### 2. Set Up Emulator (Optional)

If you want to use the `cpc run` command, configure your emulator path:

<Steps>

1. Download **RetroVirtualMachine** from [retrovirtualmachine.org](https://www.retrovirtualmachine.org/)

2. Install the emulator on your system

3. Configure the path in CPCReady:
   
   ```bash
   poetry run cpc configweb
   ```
   
   Or edit `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml` directly:
   
   <Tabs>
     <TabItem label="macOS">
     ```toml
     [emulator]
     retro_virtual_machine_path = "/Applications/Retro Virtual Machine 2.app"
     ```
     </TabItem>
     
     <TabItem label="Linux">
     ```toml
     [emulator]
     retro_virtual_machine_path = "/usr/local/bin/RetroVirtualMachine"
     ```
     </TabItem>
     
     <TabItem label="Windows (WSL)">
     ```toml
     [emulator]
     retro_virtual_machine_path = "/mnt/c/Program Files/RetroVirtualMachine/rvm.exe"
     ```
     </TabItem>
   </Tabs>

</Steps>

## Verify Installation

Test your installation with these commands:

```bash
# Check version
poetry run cpc --version

# View help
poetry run cpc --help

# Create a test disk
poetry run cpc disc new test.dsk

# Mount the disk
poetry run cpc drive A test.dsk

# List files (should be empty)
poetry run cpc cat
```

<Aside type="tip" title="Success!">
If all commands run without errors, CPCReady is correctly installed and ready to use.
</Aside>

## Updating CPCReady

To update to the latest version:

```bash
cd /path/to/cpc
git pull origin main
poetry install
```

## Troubleshooting

### Poetry not found

If `poetry` command is not found, add it to your PATH:

```bash
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
```

Add this line to your `~/.bashrc` or `~/.zshrc` to make it permanent.

### Python version issues

Ensure you have Python 3.13 or higher:

```bash
python3 --version
```

If needed, install a newer version from [python.org](https://www.python.org/downloads/).

### Permission errors

On Linux/macOS, you may need to run with appropriate permissions:

```bash
sudo poetry install
```

### WSL-specific issues

On Windows with WSL, ensure you're using the Linux version of Python, not the Windows version.

<Card>Manage virtual floppy drives A and B: mount DSK files, check status, and eject disks.</Card>

## Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc drive [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Virtual drive management commands.

Commands:
  A       Mount DSK file in drive A
  B       Mount DSK file in drive B
  status  Display current disk status
  eject   Eject disk from drive
```

---

<Tabs>
<TabItem label="drive A">

## drive A

Mount a DSK file in virtual drive A. Validates the file path and updates configuration for subsequent operations.

### Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc drive A [OPTIONS] DSK_FILE

  Mount DSK file in drive A.

Arguments:
  DSK_FILE  Path to the DSK file to mount

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### Examples

#### Mount disk in current directory
```bash
cpc drive A system.dsk
```

#### Mount disk with absolute path
```bash
cpc drive A /Users/user/cpc/games.dsk
```

#### Mount disk with relative path
```bash
cpc drive A ../disks/backup.dsk
```

<Aside type="caution">
If the DSK file doesn't exist, the command will display an error and won't modify the configuration.
</Aside>

<Aside type="tip">
Use `cpc drive status` to verify the disk is mounted correctly.
</Aside>

</TabItem>

<TabItem label="drive B">

## drive B

Mount a DSK file in virtual drive B. Validates the file path and updates configuration for subsequent operations.

### Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc drive B [OPTIONS] DSK_FILE

  Mount DSK file in drive B.

Arguments:
  DSK_FILE  Path to the DSK file to mount

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### Examples

#### Mount disk in current directory
```bash
cpc drive B games.dsk
```

#### Mount disk with absolute path
```bash
cpc drive B /Users/user/cpc/utilities.dsk
```

#### Mount disk with relative path
```bash
cpc drive B ../../oldstuff/archive.dsk
```

<Aside type="caution">
If the DSK file doesn't exist, the command will display an error and won't modify the configuration.
</Aside>

<Aside type="tip">
Use `cpc drive status` to verify the disk is mounted correctly.
</Aside>

</TabItem>

<TabItem label="drive status">

## drive status

Display the current status of both floppy drives, showing which DSK files are mounted and their paths.

### Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc drive status [OPTIONS]

  Display current disk status for drives A and B.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### Examples

#### Display drive status
```bash
cpc drive status
```

#### Alternative command
```bash
cpcdrivestatus
```

<Aside type="tip">
Shows which DSK files are currently mounted in drives A and B, along with their full paths.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
Drive configuration is stored in `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml` under the `[drive]` section.
</Aside>

</TabItem>

<TabItem label="drive eject">

## drive eject

Eject (unmount) the currently inserted DSK disk from drive A or B, clearing the drive configuration.

### Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc drive eject [OPTIONS]

  Eject disk from drive A or B.

Options:
  -A, --drive-a  Eject from drive A
  -B, --drive-b  Eject from drive B
  --help         Show this message and exit.
```

### Examples

#### Eject from drive A
```bash
cpc drive eject -A
```

#### Eject from drive B
```bash
cpc drive eject -B
```

#### Alternative command (drive A)
```bash
cpcdriveeject -A
```

#### Alternative command (drive B)
```bash
cpcdriveeject -B
```

<Aside type="tip">
Use `cpc drive status` after ejecting to verify the drive is empty.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
Ejecting removes the DSK path from `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml` for the specified drive.
</Aside>

</TabItem>

<Card>Delete (erase) a file from the currently mounted DSK disk. Supports wildcards for batch deletion.</Card>

## Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc era [OPTIONS] PATTERN

  Delete file(s) from DSK disk.

Arguments:
  PATTERN  File pattern to delete (supports wildcards: *, ?)

Options:
  -A, --drive-a  Delete from drive A (default)
  -B, --drive-b  Delete from drive B
  --help         Show this message and exit.
```

## Examples

### Delete specific file
```bash
cpc era GAME.BAS
```

### Delete all .BAK files
```bash
cpc era *.BAK
```

### Delete from drive B
```bash
cpc era OLDFILE.BIN -B
```

### Delete all files starting with TEST
```bash
cpc era TEST*.*
```

### Alternative command
```bash
cpcera MYFILE.TXT
```

<video controls width="800" autoplay loop muted>
  <source src="/videos/cat.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
</video>

<Aside type="caution">
**Deletion is permanent!** Files are removed from the DSK without confirmation. Make backups before using wildcards.
</Aside>

<Aside type="tip">
Wildcards:  
**\*** matches any characters  
**?** matches single character  
Example: `DATA?.BIN` matches DATA1.BIN, DATA2.BIN, etc.
</Aside>

import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Card } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Aside } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Tabs, TabItem } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; Manage DSK disk images: create new disks, insert existing ones, and display detailed information about disk structure and content. ## Usage ```bash Usage: cpc disc [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]... Disk image management commands. Commands: new Create a new blank DSK disk image insert Insert existing DSK into drive A or B info Show detailed information about disk ``` --- ## disc new Create a new blank DSK disk image file with standard CPC format (40 tracks, 9 sectors per track, 512 bytes per sector). ### Usage ```bash Usage: cpc disc new [OPTIONS] DSK_FILE Create a new blank DSK disk image. Arguments: DSK_FILE Path to the DSK file to create Options: --help Show this message and exit. ``` ### Examples #### Create blank disk in current directory ```bash cpc disc new mydisk.dsk ``` #### Create disk with full path ```bash cpc disc new /path/to/newdisk.dsk ``` #### Alternative command ```bash cpcdisc new blank.dsk ```
If the DSK file already exists, this command will **overwrite** it without confirmation.
Creates a standard CPC Data format disk: 40 tracks 9 sectors 512 bytes = 180KB capacity.
## disc insert Insert an existing DSK file into virtual drive A or B. The command validates file existence and updates drive configuration. ### Usage ```bash Usage: cpc disc insert [OPTIONS] DSK_FILE Insert existing DSK into drive A or B. Arguments: DSK_FILE Path to the DSK file to insert Options: -A, --drive-a Insert into drive A -B, --drive-b Insert into drive B --help Show this message and exit. ``` ### Examples #### Insert disk into drive A ```bash cpc disc insert game.dsk -A ``` #### Insert disk into drive B with relative path ```bash cpc disc insert ../disks/system.dsk -B ``` #### Alternative command ```bash cpcdisc insert backup.dsk -A ```
You must specify either `-A` or `-B`. The command will fail if: - Neither drive option is specified - Both drive options are specified - The DSK file doesn't exist
Use `cpc drive status` after inserting to verify the disk is mounted correctly.
## disc info Display detailed information about a disk image including structure, format, capacity, file types, and block usage. ### Usage ```bash Usage: cpc disc info [OPTIONS] [DSK_FILE] Show detailed information about a disc file. Arguments: DSK_FILE Path to DSK file (optional if using drive option) Options: -A, --drive-a Show info for disc in drive A -B, --drive-b Show info for disc in drive B --help Show this message and exit. ``` ### Information Displayed
  • Structure: Tracks, size, sides
  • Format: Disk type, sector information
  • Capacity: Total, used, free space
  • File Types: BASIC, Binary, ASCII counts
  • Blocks: Used blocks, first allocated block
### Examples #### Show info for disk in drive A ```bash cpc disc info -A ``` #### Show info for specific DSK file ```bash cpc disc info mydisk.dsk ``` #### Show info for disk in drive B ```bash cpc disc info -B ``` #### Alternative command ```bash cpcdisc info -A ```
Without options, the command uses the default drive (usually A).

Display BASIC file content from DSK

import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Card } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Aside } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

<Card>Display the contents of BASIC files stored on DSK disk images. Supports tokenized and ASCII BASIC formats with syntax highlighting.</Card>

## Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc list [OPTIONS] FILE_NAME

  List BASIC file from virtual disc.

Arguments:
  FILE_NAME  Name of BASIC file to display

Options:
  -A, --drive-a  Read from drive A (default)
  -B, --drive-b  Read from drive B
  --help         Show this message and exit.
```

## Features

- **Tokenized BASIC**: Automatically detokenizes Locomotive BASIC files
- **ASCII BASIC**: Displays plain text BASIC files
- **Syntax Highlighting**: Rich console output with color coding
- **Format Detection**: Auto-detects BASIC format (tokenized vs ASCII)
- **Binary Detection**: Warns if file is binary (not BASIC)

## Examples

### List BASIC file from drive A
```bash
cpc list GAME.BAS
```

### List BASIC file from drive B
```bash
cpc list MENU.BAS -B
```

### Alternative command
```bash
cpclist PROGRAM.BAS
```

### Display tokenized BASIC
```bash
cpc list LOADER.BAS
```

<video controls width="800" autoplay loop muted>
  <source src="/videos/cat.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
</video>

<Aside type="tip">
The command automatically detects the BASIC format:
- **Tokenized**: Binary format with BASIC tokens (most CPC programs)
- **ASCII**: Plain text format created with editors or `SAVE "FILE",A`
</Aside>

<Aside type="caution">
If you try to list a binary file (type 2), the command will display an error message:
```
Error: FILE.BIN is a BINARY file (type 2), not a BASIC program.
Use 'cpc filextr' to extract binary files.
```
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
The command respects the current user number (see `cpc user`). Only files in the active user area will be accessible.
</Aside>

Save files to DSK disk with AMSDOS headers

import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Card } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Aside } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

<Card>Save files to DSK disk images with automatic or manual AMSDOS header creation. Supports binary, BASIC, and ASCII file types with hex or decimal addresses.</Card>

## Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc save [OPTIONS] FILE_NAME [TYPE] [LOAD_ADDR] [EXEC_ADDR]

  Save file to virtual disc with AMSDOS header.

Arguments:
  FILE_NAME   File to save (required)
  TYPE        File type: 'b' (binary), 'p' (program), 'a' (ASCII), 'auto' (default)
  LOAD_ADDR   Load address in hex (0x5BCC, &5BCC) or decimal (23500)
  EXEC_ADDR   Execution address in hex or decimal

Options:
  -A, --drive-a  Save to drive A (default)
  -B, --drive-b  Save to drive B
  --help         Show this message and exit.
```

## File Types

- **auto** (default): Detects type from content/extension
  - `.BIN` files  Binary with header
  - `.BAS` files  BASIC ASCII
  - Files with AMSDOS header  Preserves header
  - Other files  ASCII without header

- **b** (binary): Binary file with specific load/exec addresses
  - Requires LOAD_ADDR
  - EXEC_ADDR optional (defaults to LOAD_ADDR)
  - Adds AMSDOS header with type=2

- **p** (program): Program with AMSDOS header
  - Uses detected or specified addresses
  - Sets read-only attribute

- **a** (ASCII): Plain ASCII/data file
  - No AMSDOS header
  - Suitable for text files

## Address Formats

Addresses can be specified in three formats:

- **Hexadecimal with 0x**: `0x5BCC`
- **Hexadecimal with &**: `&5BCC`
- **Decimal**: `23500`

## Examples

### Auto-detect file type
```bash
cpc save game.bin
```

### Save binary with hex addresses
```bash
cpc save 8bp.bin b 0x5BCC 0x4ABF
```

### Save binary with decimal addresses
```bash
cpc save screen.bin b 23500 19119
```

### Save binary with & notation
```bash
cpc save loader.bin b &4000 &4000
```

### Save BASIC ASCII file
```bash
cpc save program.bas a
```

### Save to drive B
```bash
cpc save data.bin b 0x8000 -B
```

### Alternative command
```bash
cpcsave myfile.bin b 0x4000
```

<video controls width="800" autoplay loop muted>
  <source src="/videos/cat.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
</video>

<Aside type="tip">
**Address conversion examples:**
- `0x5BCC` = `&5BCC` = `23500` (decimal)
- `0x4ABF` = `&4ABF` = `19119` (decimal)
- `0x4000` = `&4000` = `16384` (decimal)
</Aside>

<Aside type="caution">
Binary type 'b' requires at least the load address. If execution address is omitted, it defaults to the load address.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
Files are saved to the current user number (see `cpc user`). The disk automatically updates its directory after saving.
</Aside>

Consola interactiva con barra de estado

import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Card } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import { Aside } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

<Card>Lanza una consola interactiva con barra de estado que muestra informacin en tiempo real del sistema CPC. 
La consola proporciona acceso completo a todos los comandos de CPCReady con historial y autocompletado.</Card>

## Uso

El comando se ejecuta utilizando el comando principal <Badge text="cpc" variant="note" />
pasndole como argumento el subcomando <Badge text="console" variant="tip" />

```bash
Usage: cpc console [OPTIONS]

  Interactive console with bottom status toolbar

Options:
  --version  Show version and exit
  --help     Show this message and exit.
```

## Caractersticas

### Barra de Estado Inferior

La consola muestra una barra de estado persistente en la parte inferior con:

- **Logo Amstrad**: Crculos de colores distintivos ()
- **Modelo CPC**: Muestra el modelo configurado (CPC 464, 664 o 6128)
- **Estado Drive A**: Nombre del disco montado o "Empty" si est vaco
- **Estado Drive B**: Nombre del disco montado o "Empty" si est vaco
- **Emulador**: Emulador configurado (RetroVirtualMachine, etc.)
- **Modo de Video**: Modo de pantalla actual (0, 1 o 2)

### Prompt Personalizado

El prompt muestra:
- Nombre de la aplicacin: <Badge text="CPCReady" variant="success" />
- Directorio actual de trabajo
- Indicador de entrada: <Badge text="~>" variant="tip" />

### Funcionalidades Interactivas

- **Historial de Comandos**: Navega comandos anteriores con  y 
- **Autocompletado**: Presiona Tab para autocompletar comandos y archivos
- **Persistencia de Estado**: Los drives y configuracin se mantienen durante toda la sesin
- **Acceso Completo**: Todos los comandos `cpc` estn disponibles directamente

## Comandos Disponibles

Dentro de la consola puedes ejecutar todos los comandos de CPCReady sin el prefijo `cpc`:

```bash
CPCReady ~/path ~> cat              # Listar archivos del disco
CPCReady ~/path ~> list test.bas    # Ver programa BASIC
CPCReady ~/path ~> save file.bin b 0x4000 0x4000  # Guardar binario
CPCReady ~/path ~> drive status     # Ver estado de drives
CPCReady ~/path ~> model 6128       # Cambiar modelo CPC
CPCReady ~/path ~> exit             # Salir de la consola
```

## Ejemplos

### Iniciar la Consola

```bash
cpc console
```

### Flujo de Trabajo Tpico

```bash
# Iniciar consola
$ cpc console

# Montar disco en drive A
CPCReady ~/path ~> drive a test.dsk

# Ver archivos
CPCReady ~/path ~> cat

# Guardar un archivo
CPCReady ~/path ~> save game.bas

# Listar programa BASIC
CPCReady ~/path ~> list game.bas

# Cambiar modelo
CPCReady ~/path ~> model 6128

# Ejecutar en emulador
CPCReady ~/path ~> run game.bas

# Salir
CPCReady ~/path ~> exit
```

Configure the default emulator to use

import { Badge } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

<Card>Select the default emulator for running CPC software. Choose between RetroVirtualMachine or M4Board with an interactive menu.</Card>

## Usage

```bash
Usage: cpc emu [OPTIONS]

  Configure the emulator to use.

  Select between M4Board or RetroVirtualMachine as the default emulator.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

## Examples

### Select emulator interactively

```bash
cpc emu
```

**Interactive prompt:**
```
 Current emulator: RetroVirtualMachine

? Select emulator to use: 
 RetroVirtualMachine
  M4Board
```

**After selection:**
```
 Emulator set to: M4Board
```

### Cancel selection

Press `ESC` or `Ctrl+C` to cancel:

```
 Current emulator: RetroVirtualMachine

? Select emulator to use: 
 RetroVirtualMachine
  M4Board

 Configuration cancelled.
```

<video controls width="800" autoplay loop muted>
  <source src="/videos/cat.mp4" type="video/mp4" />
</video>

## Available Emulators

<Card title=" RetroVirtualMachine">
**RetroVirtualMachine** is a multi-platform emulator that provides accurate Amstrad CPC emulation.

- **Platform:** macOS, Windows, Linux
- **Features:** High accuracy, full peripherals support
- **Configuration:** Use [`cpc rvm config`](/reference/commands/rvm/) to set path
- **Validation:** Requires specific version (v2.0 BETA-1 r7)
</Card>

<Card title=" M4Board">
**M4Board** is a physical hardware add-on for real Amstrad CPC computers.

- **Platform:** Real CPC hardware with M4 board
- **Features:** Direct hardware execution, SD card support
- **Configuration:** Requires M4Board connected to your CPC
- **Speed:** Native CPC hardware speed
</Card>

## Configuration Storage

The selected emulator is stored in your configuration file:

**Location:** `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml`

**Format:**
```toml
[emulator]
selected = "RetroVirtualMachine"
```

Or:
```toml
[emulator]
selected = "M4Board"
```

## Features

<Card title=" Interactive Selection">
Uses Questionary for a clean, user-friendly menu interface with keyboard navigation.
</Card>

<Card title=" Current State Display">
Shows the currently configured emulator before prompting for selection.
</Card>

<Card title=" Persistent Configuration">
Saves your selection to the TOML configuration file for future sessions.
</Card>

<Card title=" Easy Switching">
Quickly switch between emulators without editing configuration files manually.
</Card>

## How It Works

1. **Display current emulator** - Shows what's currently configured
2. **Present selection menu** - Interactive list with arrow key navigation
3. **Highlight default** - Current emulator is pre-selected
4. **Save choice** - Updates configuration file automatically
5. **Confirm change** - Shows success message with selected emulator

## Navigation

- **/ Arrow keys** - Navigate between options
- **Enter** - Confirm selection
- **ESC/Ctrl+C** - Cancel without changes

<Aside type="tip">
The selected emulator is used by the [`run`](/reference/commands/run/) command when launching software.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
After changing the emulator, make sure it's properly configured:
- For RetroVirtualMachine: Use `cpc rvm config` to set the path
- For M4Board: Ensure the board is connected and configured
</Aside>

## Related Commands

- [`rvm`](/reference/commands/rvm/) - Configure RetroVirtualMachine settings
- [`run`](/reference/commands/run/) - Launch software with selected emulator
- [`configweb`](/reference/commands/configweb/) - Web interface for all settings
- [`settings`](/reference/commands/settings/) - Command-line settings management

## Use Cases

### Development Workflow

Switch to RetroVirtualMachine for quick testing and debugging:
```bash
cpc emu  # Select RetroVirtualMachine
cpc run GAME.BAS
```

### Real Hardware Testing

Switch to M4Board for final testing on real hardware:
```bash
cpc emu  # Select M4Board
cpc run GAME.BAS
```

### Multi-Platform Development

Easily test your software on both emulator and real hardware without editing configuration files.

<Card>Control and manage M4Board hardware add-on for real Amstrad CPC computers. Upload files, execute programs, and manage the SD card remotely over network.</Card>

## Overview

The M4Board is a physical hardware add-on for real Amstrad CPC computers that provides:
- SD card storage for CPC programs
- Network connectivity for remote file management
- ROM management capabilities
- Direct execution on real CPC hardware

## Subcommands

### m4 status

Check M4Board connection status and verify network connectivity.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 status [OPTIONS]

  Check M4Board connection status.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 config

Configure M4Board IP address with connection validation.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 config [OPTIONS]

  Configure M4Board IP address.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 push

Upload a file to M4Board SD card.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 push [OPTIONS] FILE_PATH

  Upload a file to M4Board SD card.

  FILE_PATH: Local file to upload

Options:
  -d, --destination TEXT  Destination directory on SD card
  -h, --header            Add AMSDOS header
  --help                  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 pull

Download a file from M4Board SD card.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 pull [OPTIONS] CPC_PATH

  Download a file from M4Board SD card.

  CPC_PATH: File path on M4Board SD card

Options:
  -o, --output TEXT  Local output file path
  --help             Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 exec

Execute a file on the CPC.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 exec [OPTIONS] CPC_FILE

  Execute a file on CPC.

  CPC_FILE: File path on M4Board SD card to execute

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 run

Upload and execute a file in one command.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 run [OPTIONS] FILE_PATH

  Upload and execute a file on CPC.

  FILE_PATH: Local file to upload and execute

Options:
  -d, --destination TEXT  Destination directory (default: /tmp)
  --help                  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 mkdir

Create a directory on the SD card.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 mkdir [OPTIONS] FOLDER

  Create a directory on M4Board SD card.

  FOLDER: Directory path to create

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 cd

Change current directory on CPC.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 cd [OPTIONS] FOLDER

  Change current directory on CPC.

  FOLDER: Directory path

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 ls

List files in a directory.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 ls [OPTIONS] [FOLDER]

  List files in a directory on CPC.

  FOLDER: Directory to list (default: current directory)

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 rm

Remove a file or empty directory.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 rm [OPTIONS] CPC_FILE

  Remove a file or empty directory on CPC.

  CPC_FILE: File or directory to remove

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 reset-m4

Reset the M4Board hardware.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 reset-m4 [OPTIONS]

  Reset M4Board.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 reset-cpc

Reset the CPC computer.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 reset-cpc [OPTIONS]

  Reset CPC.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### m4 pause

Pause CPC execution.

```bash
Usage: cpc m4 pause [OPTIONS]

  Pause CPC execution.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

## Features

<Card title=" Connection Validation">
All commands automatically check M4Board connectivity before executing operations. If the board is not reachable, operations are aborted with clear error messages.
</Card>

<Card title=" File Transfer">
Upload and download files between your computer and M4Board SD card over the network. Supports custom destination directories and AMSDOS headers.
</Card>

<Card title=" Quick Execution">
The `run` command combines upload and execution in a single operation, uploading the file to `/tmp` and immediately executing it.
</Card>

<Card title=" Directory Management">
Full directory operations: create, navigate, list, and remove directories on the M4Board SD card.
</Card>

<Card title=" System Control">
Remote reset capabilities for both M4Board and CPC, plus pause functionality for debugging.
</Card>

<Card title=" Interactive Configuration">
User-friendly IP configuration with automatic connection testing before saving settings.
</Card>

## Network Requirements

### M4Board Network Setup

1. **Connect M4Board to network** - Ethernet cable from M4Board to router/switch
2. **Assign static IP** - Configure M4Board with a fixed IP address
3. **Note the IP** - You'll need this for CPCReady configuration

### Firewall Configuration

Ensure your firewall allows:
- **HTTP (port 80)** - For M4Board web interface
- **Outbound connections** - From your computer to M4Board IP

## Common Workflows

### Development Workflow

Develop and test on real hardware:
```bash
# 1. Edit your program locally
# 2. Upload and run
cpc m4 run myprogram.bin

# 3. If it crashes, reset and try again
cpc m4 reset-cpc
cpc m4 run myprogram.bin
```

### File Organization

Organize files on SD card:
```bash
# Create project structure
cpc m4 mkdir /projects
cpc m4 mkdir /projects/game1

# Upload files
cpc m4 push sprite.bin -d /projects/game1
cpc m4 push music.bin -d /projects/game1
cpc m4 push main.bin -d /projects/game1

# List to verify
cpc m4 ls /projects/game1
```

### Backup and Restore

Download files from M4Board:
```bash
# Backup a save file
cpc m4 pull /saves/game.sav -o backup_game.sav

# Later, restore it
cpc m4 push backup_game.sav -d /saves
```

<Aside type="tip">
Use the `run` command during development for quick iterations. It automatically uploads to `/tmp` and executes, saving you from managing file locations.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
The M4Board must be powered on and connected to the same network as your computer. Check network connectivity with `cpc m4 status` before operations.
</Aside>

<Aside type="caution" title="Network Security">
The M4Board web interface is unencrypted HTTP. Only use on trusted local networks. Do not expose M4Board directly to the internet.
</Aside>

## Troubleshooting

### Cannot Connect to M4Board

**Problem:** `M4Board is not reachable`

**Solutions:**
1. Verify M4Board is powered on
2. Check Ethernet cable connection
3. Ping the IP address: `ping 192.168.1.100`
4. Verify IP address is correct in config
5. Check firewall settings
6. Ensure M4Board and computer are on same network

### Upload Fails

**Problem:** File upload returns error

**Solutions:**
1. Check SD card is inserted in M4Board
2. Verify SD card has free space
3. Check file permissions (readable)
4. Ensure destination directory exists
5. Try creating directory first: `cpc m4 mkdir /games`

### Execution Does Nothing

**Problem:** `exec` command succeeds but program doesn't run

**Solutions:**
1. Verify file path is correct
2. Check file is executable format
3. Try with full path: `/games/program.bin`
4. Reset CPC and try again: `cpc m4 reset-cpc`

## Technical Details

### Communication Protocol

- **Protocol:** HTTP REST API
- **Port:** 80 (HTTP)
- **Timeout:** 2-30 seconds depending on operation
- **User-Agent:** `cpcready`

### File Upload

- **Endpoint:** `/upload.html`
- **Method:** POST multipart/form-data
- **Max File Size:** Limited by M4Board firmware

### Commands

All commands use GET requests to `/config.cgi` with specific parameters:
- `?mres` - Reset M4
- `?cres` - Reset CPC
- `?run2=<file>` - Execute file
- `?mkdir=<path>` - Create directory
- `?cd=<path>` - Change directory
- `?rm=<file>` - Remove file
- `?ls=<path>` - List directory
- `?chlt=CPC+Pause` - Pause CPC

<Card>Manage RetroVirtualMachine emulator configuration, validate installation and check version compatibility.

## Subcommands

### rvm status

Check RetroVirtualMachine installation and version compatibility.

```bash
Usage: cpc rvm status [OPTIONS]

  Check RetroVirtualMachine installation and version.

  Verifies:
  - RVM path is configured
  - RVM executable exists at the configured path
  - RVM version matches the required version

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

### rvm config

Configure RetroVirtualMachine executable path with interactive prompt and validation.

```bash
Usage: cpc rvm config [OPTIONS]

  Configure RetroVirtualMachine executable path.

  Interactive prompt to set the path to RetroVirtualMachine.

  Validates that:
  - The path exists
  - The executable is accessible
  - The version matches the required version

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.
```

## Examples

### Check RVM installation status
```bash
cpc rvm status
```

**Output (success):**
```
 Configured path: /Applications/Retro Virtual Machine 2.app
 Executable found at configured path.

 RetroVirtualMachine is properly configured and ready to use.
```

**Output (version mismatch):**

## Required Version

<Aside type="caution" title="Version Requirement">
CPCReady requires **exactly** this version of RetroVirtualMachine:

- **Version:** Retro Virtual Machine v2.0 BETA-1 r7
- **Build:** MacOs x64 Build: 6783 - (Tue Jul  9 18:18:12 2019 UTC)

Other versions may not work correctly with CPCReady's automation features.
</Aside>

## Features

<Card title=" Version Validation">
Automatically validates that the configured RetroVirtualMachine matches the exact required version by executing the emulator with `--help` flag and parsing the output.
</Card>

<Card title=" Safe Configuration">
The `config` command only saves the path to configuration if validation passes. Invalid versions are rejected before being saved.
</Card>

<Card title=" Interactive Setup">
Uses Questionary for a user-friendly interactive prompt with path autocompletion and directory navigation.
</Card>

<Card title=" Path Resolution">
Automatically resolves relative paths to absolute paths and handles macOS `.app` bundles correctly.
</Card>

## Platform Support

### macOS
- **Format:** `.app` bundle (e.g., `/Applications/Retro Virtual Machine 2.app`)
- **Validation:** Locates the executable binary inside `Contents/MacOS/`
- **Execution:** Uses proper macOS application launching with `open -a`

### Windows
- **Format:** `.exe` executable
- **Validation:** Direct executable path validation
- **Execution:** Direct process spawning with DETACHED_PROCESS flag

### Linux
- **Format:** Binary executable
- **Validation:** Direct executable path validation
- **Execution:** Process spawning with new session

<Aside type="tip">
Always run `cpc rvm status` after installation or upgrade to ensure RetroVirtualMachine is properly configured.
</Aside>

<Aside type="note">
The configuration is stored in `~/.config/cpcready/cpcready.toml` under the `[emulator]` section.
</Aside>
